I'm by no means a chemist.. but i get bored I wanted to see what I could do with cinnamon I boiled the sticks in water then let them sit in my fridge over night the next day I filtered any particles out i used a paper towel so I'm sure there was still alot of small particles... I then boiled I ment to pull it off the stove while it still had water in it but wasn't paying close enough attention I walked into the kitchen with q dry pan.. so I figured It was ruined but then I noticed a residue at the bottom of the pan I scraped it out and got about 1 gram of the substance it was red sticky and tar like... I did alittle research I think what I made is cin-silin but I'm really not sure I dont don't think ingesting it is a good idea but I'm gunna try the same thing again with true cinnamon.. If I made what I think I made it can be used as a supplement for people with diabetes or people that are at risk and diabetes runs in my family so I think this might be a good thing for me

comment_text: I had to do this distillation a few years ago, but I powdered the cinnamon and bubbled steam through the solution instead of heating the solution directly. The yield is always quite low. Nice Video :)
DCM is NOT ether. DCM is methylene chloride, closely related to chloroform. You need to make a correction here before someone blows them self up. Ether is far more explosively dangerous.
For heating a sand bath works well!

An idea on a cool video would be making ammonium nitrate from calcium nitrate and ammonium sulfate. A lot of the ammonium nitrate found in cold packs is bad quality, lots of anti-caking agents etc, not to mention expensive for the amount you get.

Ca(NO3)2 + (NH4)2SO4 --> NH4NO3 + CaSO4
